text:
THE PRINCE ALBERT TIMES

BASKETWEAN REVIEW

SPINK & MAVEETY.

PRINCE ALBERT, N.W.T.

CHRISTMAS

Christmas, the greatest Feast of the Christian year, with all its promises and possibilities of joy, peace and happiness, is now upon us. The world around us is filled with cheerfulness and happiness, and we trust that the coming year will be as good as the past.

And what can we say that is new on this time-honored Feast? Nothing, absolutely nothing. We have heard of no new developments or discoveries at this season. There is nothing new under the sun, nor ever has been, except perhaps in the hearts of men. We trust that the coming year will bring us peace and happiness, and we look forward to a better future.

J. O. DAVIS & CO.

EDITORIAL NOTES

We regret that Attorney General Miller of Manitoba has gone to Toronto to meet Premier Macdonald by invitation to discuss matters of importance to both provinces and parliament. It is almost time the question was settled and a way put an end to the endless squabbles over the claims of the Dominion.

A circular has been issued by the Bishop of Manitoba calling on all members of the Church of England to attend the services at St. Paul's Cathedral on December 25th. This is the way our Lord taught us, and we should follow His example.

The Boom is off!

We are determined to sell out at a reasonable price.

BETTS & Gwynne.

PUBLIC NOTICE.

In future no notice will be given by the Prince Albert Times.

Prince Albert Dec. 21st.

Important Circular

FROM Buffalo Hall!

Owing to a change in our business, which will take effect on Jan. 1st, 1884, all accounts due and not provided for by that date, will be placed in the hands of our solicitor for collection.

WM. R. BELL.

PRICK'S BAD BOY AND HIS PA.

The Old Grandfather and His Family.

"Ah, here you are at last," said the grave old man, as he came up the stairs; "we're afraid the young fellow's been playing truant."

"Would you excuse me just a moment?"

"Of course," replied the old man, "but I shall go after a plumber for him."

"I shall have to see a doctor," said the boy, "and that's why I'm here. Are you sure you don't want me to see a doctor?"

"Yes," replied the old man, "but we'll have to see a doctor now."

ITEMS OF INTEREST

TERRITORIAL NEWS

EDMONTON

From the Edmonton News Nov. 30.

Twenty miles back last night.

Plenty of snow for sleighing.

The H.B.C. great mill is being fitted for use this winter.

W. H. Macdonald has commenced taking coal from his old drift.

J. Lumsden and party arrived from Calgary on Monday with a pack train loaded with flour and cooking utensils. His band of pioneers lost on the plains last summer were recovered at Calgary by falling into the hands of the police.

December 1st.

There is talk of new forest declared. It is said that in England what is not the public's fence is also public land.

Small hills or no grain carrying lands.

Macdonald is busy and farmers are well off at present.

It is said that the government will make a large purchase of wheat and flour.

The cold snap of the week would not be missed Wednesday, and on Wednesday night there was a heavy fall of snow.

A scout named Henry six feet tall, emerges out of the Saskatchewan river country, about eighty miles up. The face of the man is very pale.

The school closed for Tuesday evening in the school house to consider the question of incorporation, was reopened Wednesday morning.

REGINA

From the Regina News Nov. 30.

The Lieutenant Governor left on Sunday morning for Qu'Appelle Lake. He expects to arrive there shortly.

Mr. J. B. Pringle, M.P., has returned from a trip to the west. He was highly charged by his remarks. A few pairs of warm garments were distributed among the poor.

RAFFLEBOROUGH

From the Regina News Nov. 30.

The first of Mr. Raffleborough's line of stages for South Current left between the Ross, taking out three passengers.

The second stage for South Current came on the 28th, when about two inches fell, which was supplemented by an additional inch on the 29th.

The Government authorities make the first round trip on schedule time, notwithstanding several disadvantages that exist due to the commencement of such an undertaking.

Mr. B. Pringle has decided on putting up a steam gristmill with two sets of stones, to be operated during the spring season and will go east in a couple of weeks to get the necessary machinery.

An outfit of sleighs for South Current was sent out by Mr. Pringle for Chaskawill Mahaffey. A new trail suitable for winter travel is being opened which will connect the town of Allan with the town of Allan. A number of other brigades are preparing to follow.

J. D. Fitzgerald, who has a contract to deliver 500 tons of logs at Celery & Co.'s mill, Tartas River, will take his gang of men into the woods next month.

The opening of the new road across the river, will afford the settlers on the Saskatchewan a good supply of lumber for their needs. The mill will be all ready for work.

Since the resignation of Rev. Mr. Clarke as minister of the Presbyterian church at this district, the services of Macdonald and Macdonald have been put under the charge of Phillip Macdonald, who has been engaged as their alternate preacher.

EAST END.

NOTICE.

To Lumbermen and Others

What are desired of obtaining Poveshull, cut Saw Logs, House Logs, Rails, Fence Posts, Cordwood, etc., and all Kind of Timber for sale by Mr. W. H. Albert, North West Territories.

Permits will be granted in particular cases only, and only to those who are citizens of the Dominion Act, which forbids any trespassing on Crown Timber Lands.

Timber cut in any form without a permit is subject to seizure, and can be sold only to the benefit of the owner.

By order of the Minister of Interior.

Page 24 and 25, clause 60, 61 and 62 of the Dominion Land Act.

COMMUNICATIONS.

MANITOBA.

KIT PORTAGE.

From the Press.

An attempt was made last week to establish a trading post near the mouth of the Red River by Mr. Thomas O. Davis. The attempt was not successful, however, as the Indians refused to trade with him.
